questions.text: Which organism does the following life cycle correspond to?
What is the drug of choice to treat Colpitis macularis caused by Trichomonas vaginalis?

A 50-year-old man presents with persistent fatigue, chest pain, and difficulty breathing. He grew up in rural northern Argentina, where a childhood bug bite caused left eye swelling. Examination reveals leg swelling, an S3 gallop, and fatigue. IgG antibodies to Trypanosoma cruzi are detected by ELISA. Which of the following statements are true regarding this condition? Cardiac manifestations are seen in 30% with chronic form of disease. Benznidazole is considered a drug of choice for the chronic form of disease. Chronic form of disease has cardiac and gastrointestinal involvement. Peripheral blood microscopy can be used to diagnose chronic disease. The acute form of disease presents with a generalised rash.
Which of the following statements accurately describes the forms of Trypanosoma brucei that can be found in the blood of an infected individual?

options.label: A
options.text: The trypomastigote form is the only stage present in the blood.

options.label: B
options.text: The epimastigote form is commonly found in human blood during acute infection.

options.label: C
options.text: The procyclic form is typically present in the bloodstream of infected humans.

options.label: D
options.text: Both the trypomastigote and epimastigote forms can be found in human blood.

questions.correct_answer: A. The trypomastigote form is the only stage present in the blood.
questions.explanation:
West African Trypanosomiasis

East African Trypanosomiasis

Parasite

Trypanosoma gambiense

Trypanosoma rhodesiense

Vectors

Glossina palpalis

Glossina morsitans

Primary reservoirs

Man-to-man transmission

Wild game animals

Illness

Chronic
  • Acute & rapidly progressive
  • Febrile paroxysms are more frequent
  • Myocarditis is more common & death may occur due to congestive heart failure

Duration of illness

Months to years

Less than 9 months

Lymphadenopathy (Winterbottom's sign)

Prominent

Minimal

CNS involvement

Late

Early

Parasitemia

Low

High

Investigations
  • Microscopy- Trypomastigote in blood
  • Rodent inoculation- Not useful
  • Microscopy- Trypomastigote in blood
  • Rodent inoculation-Diagnostic

Treatment
  • Pentamidine
  • Eflornithine
  • Melarsoprol
  • Suramin
  • Melarsoprol

Characteristic

Trypanosoma brucei

Trypanosoma cruzi

Leishmania

Classification

Flagellate protozoan

Flagellate protozoan

Flagellate protozoan

Subtypes

T.b. gambiense, T.b. rhodesiense

-

L. donovani, L. tropica, L. braziliensis

Disease Caused

African sleeping sickness (Trypanosomiasis)

Chagas disease

L. donovani: Visceral leishmaniasis (Kala-azar)

L. tropica: Cutaneous

L. braziliensis: Mucocutaneous

Vector

Tsetse fly (Glossina)

Triatomine bug (“Kissing bug”)

Sandfly (Phlebotomus)

Infective Form

Trypomastigote

Trypomastigote

Promastigote

Chronicity / Progression

Gambiense: Slow progression

Rhodesiense: Rapid progression

Acute (mild) to Chronic (severe, e.g., cardiomyopathy, megaesophagus)

Progresses to chronic (Visceral: fatal if untreated)

Treatment

Suramin (early), Melarsoprol (late), Pentamidine and Eflornithine (alternative)

Nifurtimox, Benznidazole

Amphotericin B, Miltefosine, Sodium Stibogluconate

questions.text: A 28-year-old male returns to his rural village after spending time in a forested area known for sandfly infestations. He presents to the clinic with a painless ulcer on his forearm that has gradually increased in size over the past month, as shown in the image below. The ulcer has raised, indurated borders and a necrotic base. The patient has no fever or systemic symptoms. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Type of

Leishmaniasis

Causative Organism

Clinical Features

Treatment

Cutaneous Leishmaniasis (CL)

L. tropica (Old World)
  • Painless ulcers with raised borders and necrotic base (often called "kala-azar ulcers").
  • Three patterns: Urban (dry, painless ulcers), Rural (moist ulcers), Diffuse (non-ulcerative)
  • Antimony (same as VL) or pentamidine for antimony-resistant cases.
  • Topical treatment: Charcoal in sulfuric acid paste or liquid nitrogen

Mucocutaneous Leishmaniasis

L. braziliensis

Follows cutaneous leishmaniasis, involves nose, mouth, larynx (espundia), causing nodules, nasal septum perforation

Systemic treatment: Antimony; mucosal involvement may require additional therapies

Leishmaniasis Recidivans

L. species (varies by region)

Chronic lesions with alternating periods of activity and healing, resembling lupus or tuberculoid leprosy

Local heat application; chemotherapy not very effective; Leishmanin test strongly positive

questions.text: Identify which organism this life cycle belongs to.

A 35-year-old man presents with severe abdominal pain, dysentery, and intestinal ulcers. He reports recent travel to an area with poor sanitation. Stool examination reveals a protozoan parasite. All of the following are the features of this condition except:

options.label: B
options.text: Chromatid bar of the cyst is composed of ribonucleoprotein

options.label: D
options.text: Trophozoites produce characteristic flask-shaped ulcerative lesions

questions.explanation:
Entamoeba histolytica

Trophozoite

Cyst
  • Pointed pseudopodia
  • Single nucleus
  • Central karyosome
  • Cartwheel nucleus (Option A)
  • Erythrophagocytosis (engulfed RBCs)




 
  • 1 to 4 nucleus – Quadrinucleate
  • Thick Chromatoid body/ bar:
    • Composition: Ribonucleoprotein (RNP) (Option B)
    • Stain: Iron hematoxylin

 


 

Entamoeba histolytica

Entamoeba coli

Trophozoite

  • Pointed pseudopodia
  • 1 nucleus
  • Central karyosome
  • Cartwheel nucleus
  • Erythrophagocytosis

Trophozoite

  • Blunt pseudopodia
  • 1 nucleus
  • Eccentric karyosome
  • No cartwheel nucleus
  • No erythrophagocytosis

Cyst

  • 1 to 4 nuclei- Quadrinucleate
  • Thick chromatoid body/bar

Cyst

  • 1 to 8 nuclei- Octanucleate
  • Thin filamentous chromatoid body/bar

questions.text: A previously healthy 15-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with fever, severe headache, vomiting, and rapidly progressing confusion. He was diagnosed with meningitis, and his parents report he recently went swimming during a camping trip. Despite treatment, his condition worsens rapidly. Which of the following organisms is most likely causing this condition?

A 45-year-old man presents with 6 weeks of headaches, confusion, and cognitive decline after swimming in freshwater lakes during travel to an area with poor sanitation. Lumbar puncture shows elevated WBCs (predominantly lymphocytes) and trophozoites with distinctive spikes on their surface. Which of the following statements about the causative organism is not true?

options.label: A
options.text: It is associated with both central nervous system infections and ocular infections.

options.label: B
options.text: Both cysts and trophozoites are infective forms.

options.label: C
options.text: CT scan shows space-occupying lesions in the brain.

options.label: D
options.text: It is seen in immunocompetent individuals.

questions.correct_answer: D. It is seen in immunocompetent individuals.
questions.explanation:
Trophozoite

Cyst
 
  • Show spikes (Acantho - Spikes)

 
 
  • Double-walled, with an outer wrinkled cyst wall.

questions.text: What is the suggested treatment for the infection caused by this organism?
Which of the following statements is not true about the life cycle of Cyclospora?

options.label: A
options.text: Oocyst shed in the faeces sporulate outside the host

options.label: B
options.text: During excystation, 8 sporozoites are released from 2 sporocyst

options.label: C
options.text: Sporozoites reproduce asexually in the enterocytes

options.label: D
options.text: Autoinfection does not occur with Cyclospora

questions.correct_answer: B. During excystation, 8 sporozoites are released from 2 sporocyst
questions.explanation:
Life Cycle of Cyclospora

life cycle of cyclospora" data-author="" data-hash="11705" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="May2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/oTPuSLrjeMCQpc4YIANI1746426652.png" />1. Ingestion of Oocysts: Humans ingest sporulated oocysts from contaminated food or water.

2. Excystation: During excystation of sporulated oocyst of Cyclospora, 2 wheels release 2 sporozoites each

Release of 8 sporozoites from two sporocysts during excystation (Option B) is seen in the life cycle of Isospora (the remaining life cycle is similar to Cyclospora)

3. Invasion of Intestinal Cells: The released sporozoites invade the epithelial cells of the small intestine. (Option C)

4. Asexual Reproduction (Merogony): Merogony occurs to produce meronts 1 and then 2, which contain multiple merozoites.

5. Release of Merozoites: The merozoites are released from the infected epithelial cells into the intestinal lumen.

6. Reinfection of Host Cells: The released merozoites can invade new intestinal epithelial cells, continuing the asexual reproduction cycle.

7. Sexual Reproduction (Gametogony): Some merozoites differentiate into male (microgametes) and female (macrogametes) gametes within the host's intestinal cells

8. Fertilization and Oocyst Formation: The microgametes fertilise the macrogametes to form a zygote, which develops into an unsporulated oocyst.

 

9. Release of Oocysts: Unsporulated oocysts are excreted in the faeces of the infected host; thus, autoinfection is not possible (Option D)

10. Environmental Maturation: The oocysts sporulate in the environment and require a period of maturation before they become infective to another host.

(Option A)

11. Transmission: The mature oocysts can then contaminate food or water, leading to new infections when ingested by humans.

Both Cyclospora and Isospora complete their life cycle in a single host.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with severe diarrhoea, abdominal cramps, and weight loss. He recently returned from a tropical region and has a history of HIV with a low CD4 count. The stool analysis finding is given in the image. Which of the following statements about the identified organism is not true?

options.label: A
options.text: Cotrimoxazole is used for the treatment

questions.correct_answer: D. The incubation period is 2-14 days

Features

Cryptosporidium

Cyclospora

Cystoisospora

Transmission

Ingestion of contaminated food/water, autoinfection

Ingestion of contaminated food/water

Ingestion of sporulated oocysts

Infective form

Sporulated oocyst

Sporulated oocyst

Sporulated oocyst

Diagnostic form

Sporulated oocyst

Unsporulated oocyst

Unsporulated oocyst

Incubation Period

2-14 days

1-7 days

1-4 days

Oocyst shape

Round

Round

Oval

Oocyst size

4-6 µm

8-10 µm

20–33 µm

Sporulated oocyst

Four sporozoites

Two sporocysts, each having two sporozoites

Two sporocysts, each having four sporozoites

Acid-fastness

Uniformly acid-fast

Variable acid-fast

Uniformly acid-fast

Autofluorescence

–

++

+/-

Resistance to chlorination

+

–

–

Sporulation of the oocyst

Inside the host cells (enterocytes)

soil

soil

Zoonotic potential

Yes

Uncertain

No

Treatment

Nitazoxanide

Cotrimoxazole

Cotrimoxazole

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with two weeks of diarrhoea and abdominal pain after working on a pig farm. His stool sample reveals a ciliate protozoan. Which of the following statements is true about the protozoan?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the smallest protozoan parasite of humans

options.label: B
options.text: The infective form is the trophozoite

options.label: C
options.text: Tetracycline is the drug of choice

options.label: D
options.text: Transmission is primarily through direct contact

questions.correct_answer: C. Tetracycline is the drug of choice

questions.text: A 30-year-old man diagnosed with Plasmodium falciparum malaria presents with fever and chills after travelling to an endemic area. Which phase of the Plasmodium life cycle occurs in the human host?

options.label: A
options.text: Formation of sporozoites in the liver

options.label: B
options.text: Asexual reproduction of merozoites in red blood cells

options.label: C
options.text: Fertilization of gametocytes in the bloodstream

questions.correct_answer: B. Asexual reproduction of merozoites in red blood cells

questions.text: A 38-year-old man presents with a 7-day history of fever, chills, fatigue, and dark urine after a weekend hiking trip in rural New England. He has a temperature of 102°F (38.9°C), mild splenomegaly, and jaundice. Microscopic findings are noted below. Which of the following statements about this condition is true?

options.label: B
options.text: Presence of schizonts in blood smear

questions.correct_answer: D. Sporzoites are the infective form
questions.explanation:
Babesia

Description

Intraerythrocytic sporozoan parasite

Morphology

Trophozoites (inside RBCs) are pleomorphic (pyriform, ameboid, or spindle-like) and usually in pairs.


 

Life cycle

  • Definitive hosts: Hard ixodid tick (Option A)
  • Intermediate hosts: Rodents or mammal
  • Accidental, dead-end hosts: Human
  • Infective form: Sporozoites (Option D)
  • Sporozoites convert to trophozoites in circulation, which invade the RBCs). (Option C)
 

Clinical features

  • Malaise, fatigue, fever, chills, myalgia, arthralgia, dry cough and anorexia
  • Neck stiffness, sore throat, abdominal pain, jaundice, and anaemia are less common.
  • Severe babesiosis requires hospitalisation.

Types

Babesia microti

Babesia divergens
  • Host: Rodent
  • Mild disease with normal spleen
  • Host: Cattle
  • Severe disease, splenomectised

 

 

Microscopy

Tetrad of rings (known as Maltese cross appearance) are observed.

Management

  • Azithromycin + Atovaquone
  • Clindamycin + Quinine (severe cases)

Complications

  • Renal failure
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)
  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)
  • Congestive cardiac failure (CCF)
